title: Will Imran Khan cease to be prime minister of Pakistan before 8 December 2019?

Military runs the show; Imran is amongst the more credible faces they can have running the country as their proxy. The only risk I see - which I have not incorporated due to the short time frame here is Imran's own volatility - he may just decide to pack his bags or abuse the chief of army staff
Pakistan is a difficult country to manage with extremist always at the sidelines. Furthermore, there is not much news about the country in major dailies.

Sometimes it helps to read the "foreign" english language press.  Editor of Dawn, the Pakistan daily, was recently given the Gwenn Ifill press freedom award by Committee to Protect Journists.  https://www.dawn.com/news/1518360/press-freedom     One would think there woud be some hints of a problem voiced by the newspaper Dawn.

Street protests have a history of weakening and eliminating prime ministers so there is always a chance. However, in this case, the protests are mainly hurting the prime minister without being strong enough to remove him. https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2019/11/18/protests-in-pakistan-could-shake-prime-ministers-mandate/
Based on lack of news reports about his position
This is a guess. People may want him out, but there's very little time between now and 8 December.

The Pakistan military has declared its support for Imran Khan's government, Imran is not in danger of being held in contempt of court and President Arif Alvi, from the same party (PTI), seems to support him. These three arms of the government: Military, Supreme court, and Presidency constitute the main source of potential trouble for any pakistani prime minister. Currently, Imran Khan seems to be in good standing with all three.

Protests seeking Khan's ouster continue. The government says it can weather the disruption.
https://www.dw.com/en/pakistan-protesters-seeking-pm-imran-khans-ouster-block-streets/a-51257857
Despite some unrest and the ability of the military to intervene at short notice it appears that PM Khan is at still safe.

This is an interesting question, IMHO, but the time frame is too short.  I'd love to see it asked again with a closing date next year some time, maybe July 25th, which would mark two years since the last general election in Pakistan.  The Azadi march seems to have fizzled, and I'm inclined to think the odds Imran Khan's government will fall, or he will otherwise be removed, prior to Dec 8 of this year are less than 1%.

Imran Khan's government has been accused of being a puppet of the country's military establishment. Recent rallies (Azadi movement) by opposition parties had called for a change of guard and an end of the military interference in politics. His government is also accused of curtailing freedom of expression and denying media coverage to opposition political and civil leaders. These political factors coupled with poor economic growth and spiraling inflation signals instability in the country which if let unaddressed could lead to defeat of Imran Khan's party in the long term.  However, these internal turmoils do not indicate that Imran Khan would cease to be prime minister of Pakistan before 8 Dec 2019. Also, Imran Khan has succeeded in highlighting and exploiting the Kashmir issue which historically has diverted attention of the public from pressing problems within. This tactic is expected to work in favour of his party this time as well.

1.Debt of Pakistan is an unsolvable problem.
2. Debt service is unaffordable
3.Imran Khan's government spending is making matters much, much worse 1.Current debt As of March 2019, public debt of Pakistan is estimated to be about ₨ 35.094 trillion which is 91.2 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) of Pakistan.[2] About ₨ 18.17 trillion is owed by the government to domestic creditors, and about ₨ 1.378 trillion is owed by Public Sector Enterprises (PSEs).[2] Similarly, as of March 2019, external debt of Pakistan is now around US$105 billion.[2] Pakistan owes US$11.3 billion to Paris Club, US$27 billion to multilateral donors, US$5.765 billion to International Monetary Fund, and US$12 billion to international bonds such as Eurobond, and sukuk.[2] About fifth of the external debt which is estimated around US$19 billion is owed to China due to China-Pakistan Economic Corridor.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_debt_of_Pakistan 2.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Pakistan#Pakistan_External_Debt_Servicing_(Principal_+_Interest)[103] Imran Khan's govt borrows Rs 7.5 lakh crore in just one year, breaks all record

Will Imran Khan cease to be prime minister of Pakistan before 8 December 2019?
Short time frame.
Hattip to @Kitsonj for the analysis to back my forecast.
Death or assassination seems to be the most likely way for this question to resolve as a Yes, both of which are very unlikely to occur in the next month.
He will some how manage to bowl the people over, while putting the opposition on the back foot

Since the military rule ended in 1985, there have been 13 Pakistani prime ministers, one every 2.6 years (there was military rule from 99-08, but there were also prime ministers appointed in this time.) There doesn't seem to be an special reason for the 8th December as an end date, just a months time, although Dec 7th is national voters day in Pakistan. Khan has (obviously) said he will not back down, and the military appears to be backing him. Given the short time frame, the age of Khan, the protection around him, the backing of the military and there being no elections in the time period I am going low on this one.

As the protests stand currently, it is unlikely that there will be sufficient pressure to remove him from office, and he is unlikely to resign. His government's anti-corruption campaign seems genuine, and the opposition's pro-Taliban sentiments are reportedly unpopular with a majority of Pakistanis.  Highly unlikely that he will resign, and even less likely that he will be removed from office before 12/8/2019
He is very new Prime Minister. He is charismatic, clever, full of fresh and safer ideas for new generation. He is going to stay for longer time.
